awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Development of a Smart Health Management System for Respiratory Patients
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be the redefinition of the care of asthma patients. Asthma is highly prevalent in the US, with 25 million patients currently suffering symptoms, and was the cause of 1.7 million emergency room visits in 2015, resulting in a huge societal cost. A predictive platform that can identify when a patient is at risk of an asthma attack would serve to reduce such costs by allowing intervention in a timely manner, thereby reducing the number of emergency room visits by asthma patients. Through the combination of remote monitoring of patient lung function, local environmental sensing, and data analytics, asthma can be understood at a personalized scale, a dramatic shift in the standard of care for this chronic and complex condition. Additionally, the platform developed in this project can be expanded to other conditions, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder or cystic fibrosis, broadening its impact. Ultimately, it is envisioned that this project will result in a world without asthma attacks.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will result in the development of a machine learning-based data analytics platform to identify in advance when asthma patients are at risk of an asthma attack, thereby enabling physicians to alter a patient's care plan and avoid hospitalization. To date, there is no integrated system to gather and analyze high-quality lung function and environmental data for asthma patients on a daily basis in order to truly analyze and predict a patient's health. As a result, asthma care is often reactive, requiring emergency treatment and resulting in poor clinical outcomes. The objectives of this Phase II research include the development and validation of a machine-learning based analytics model to generate new insights into the health of asthma patients; the development and implementation of a physician portal to translate such insights into clinical outcomes; and the development of new datasets to create a more robust and accurate platform. The result will be a live prediction platform to assist physicians in keeping asthma patients out of the emergency room.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Asthma and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) are conditions impacting the lives of over 40 million Americans. Additionally, over 5.5 million Americans live more than an hour from their nearest pulmonologist, and there is a shortage of ~1,400 pulmonologists in the United States. This hurts patients' access to appropriate care for asthma and COPD.

A solution that VitalFlo is pursuing is to enable better diagnostics in the primary care setting, which would allow for greater access to initial care and treatments. Unfortunately, primary care diagnoses are unreliable: only 30% of cases are accurately diagnosed (with the remainder either over- or under-diagnosed). Part of this challenge is because the primary diagnostic tool available to primary care providers (PCPs) is spirometry: which PCPs can find difficult to use and interpret accurately.

VitalFlo has developed a software platform that reliably improves the ease-of-use of spirometry testing and interpretation. However, it still requires clinical expertise to arrive at a conclusive diagnoses.

This SBIR Phase II grant enabled VitalFlo to research a solution to this problem: VitalFlo sought to develop an automated diagnostic clinical tool for use in the primary care setting.

To accomplish this, VitalFlo’s primary goal was to develop an image classification algorithm applying modern machine learning techniques to individual patient flow-volume loops. Flow-volume loops are the primary graph resulting from an accurate spirometry test, and frequently are in the patient electronic health record as unstructured data in a PDF format.

In developing this algorithm, VitalFlo accomplished its objectives to acquire, clean, and analyze population-level respiratory health data. VitalFlo set further objectives to utilize this comprehensive data analysis in developing, training, and testing the image classification algorithm.

VitalFlo has successfully achieved our proposed objectives in developing an image classification algorithm for respiratory diagnosis. In building the algorithm, we first focused on constructing a pipeline to extract large volumes of respiratory data from spirometry data stored in PDF files, the conventional format used by many clinics and hospitals in the US.

The data that was used was accessed in partnership with Family Allergy & Asthma Research Institute. The data provided was formatted as PDFs with expert spirometry interpretations were included in each report based on evaluation of the flow-volume and volume-time loops, as well as calculated lung function values. If lung pathology was present, it was reported as either “restriction” or “obstruction” along with a severity grading of “mild”, “moderate”, “moderately severe”, or “severe”.

With the extracted data, VitalFlo trained our machine learning model to develop a proof of concept for an automated clinical diagnostic. While our team considered and tested a number of different machine learning model architectures in development of the final image classification algorithm, including support vector machine (SVM), random forest (RF), and K-neural networks (KNN), consultation with our team members who hold technical expertise in machine learning model building and implementation indicated that a convolutional neural network model (CNN) would be best suited for our goals.

This was an iterative process, and the final CNN model had a training accuracy of 97.1% and validation accuracy of 100.0% on epoch 20 (of 20), which may indicate some degree of overfitting, particularly for flow-volume loops representing normal spirometry. As expected, model performance was best in the normal spirometry class (80.2% accuracy), followed by severe obstruction (20.0%), mild-moderate obstruction (18.8%), mild-moderate restriction (14.7%), and worst in the severe restriction class (0.0% accuracy).

In summary, this grant supported work to create an image classification algorithm that utilizes only spirometry flow-volume loops with convolutional neural network methods to identify normal and pathologic patterns of respiratory function. Furthermore, the developed model can accurately assign severity to pathologic patterns for asthma. We anticipate the further commercialization and development of this grant-supported technology.


Last Modified: 12/13/2024
Modified by: Luke G Marshall
